text.p: A Croat ambush on Moslems visiting a cemetery has illustrated the international community's utter failure to reunite the city and its willingness to tolerate nationalist hard-liners, analysts say.

Three years since the war between Croats and Moslems ended, ultra-nationalists and their criminal allies are still firmly entrenched in Croat-held western Mostar, U.N. relief workers and diplomats say.
"The war has ended but not much else has changed here," said one U.N. relief official.
Generous infusions of financial aid and patient diplomacy have done nothing to alter the communal divide between Bosnian Moslems and Croats in Mostar.
Some of the buildings that were destroyed in 10 months of Moslem-Croat war had been repaired with European money, but people in Mostar live in a partitioned town.

The former front-line that straddles the Neretva River serves as an unofficial Berlin Wall. Policemen stand at street corners ready to stop anyone with wrong registration plates, despite pledges to allow "freedom of movement".
Monday's violence, in which Croats opened fire at Moslems visiting a graveyard in the Croat-held western sector, drew strong condemnation from Western governments.
But diplomatic protests are unlikely to change the political landscape in Mostar. Diplomats say Croats opposed to co-existence with Moslems have learned they can act with virtual impunity.
The same men who drove Moslems from western Mostar and blew up the town's ancient Ottoman bridge still hold the reins and refuse to recognise an elected city administration.
The hard-liners include the former mayor of western Mostar Mijo Brajkovic, who still exerts influence as head of the nationalist Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) party.
Two prominent gangsters, who have close ties to the HDZ hard-liners, have profited mightily of the expulsions of Moslems from the western Mostar, diplomats say.
"This is what is so disgusting -- the mafia is so closely connected to the authorities", said a U.N. official.
The Mostar Croats enjoy close ties to Gojko Susak, the powerful Croatian defence minister who armed and supported Croat separatists throughout the Bosnian conflict.
Susak and some of the main Bosnian Croat hard-liner nationalists share the same birthplace in Herzegovina region.
The United States and its European allies have repeatedly demanded that Susak and Croatian President Franjo Tudjman force their HDZ proteges to halt ethnic cleansing and nationalist obstruction.
But the Zagreb government said its influence is "limited" in Bosnia.
Relief workers, U.N. monitors and diplomats said they were discouraged by the clash at the cemetery but ruled out the possibility of a new war erupting in Mostar.
Despite rising tensions, the heavily armed NATO-led peace force is seen as a guarantor that the peace will hold in Mostar and elsewhere in Bosnia.
NATO officers say both Croats and Moslems are aware that neither side enjoys sufficient military strength to be confident of defeating the other in a possible conflict.
Balkan analysts warn that Croat obstruction has strengthened hard-liners among the Moslems and planted seeds for an eventual collision.
They say only indefinite deployment of NATO troops will keep the guns silent or forceful action to oust the hard-liners.
